subject: Re: [junit] The upcoming "assert" keyword in JDK 1.4
msgSnippet: assert has been deprecated in JUnit, replaced by assertTrue(). Of course, that still leaves hundreds of existing references to change (per project),
messageBody:
"assert" has been deprecated in JUnit, replaced by assertTrue().

<rant>Of course, that still leaves hundreds of existing references to
change (per project), but Sun didn't appear to care, even though it was
hardly necessary for them to make it a reserved word, much less add a new
gramattical production to the language. It's worse for use, since we have
a support package named "assert" which all of our packages depend on, so
we can't just deprecate a single method.

It always amazes me when folks go through the trouble to create a nice,
object oriented language with hierarchical namespaces and can't figure
out how to add a feature without modifying the syntax.
</rant>

OK, I feel a little better.

On Wed, 3 Oct 2001, Green, Noah wrote:

>
> Preliminary research by me and co-workers indicates that Sun is adding an
> assertion facility to JDK 1.4. If this happens the way it says in the
> documentation, "assert" will become a reserved keyword in the Java language.
> Here is the Sun page detailing the new assertion facility:
> http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/docs/guide/lang/assert.html
> Note that it seems this is already in the beta of JDK 1.4.
>
> The document also details ways of turning off assertions, including the fact
> that you must use a special setting at compile time in order
> for assertions to work at all:
> http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/docs/guide/lang/assert.html#compiling
>
> The question is whether not using this compile-time setting frees up the
> "assert" keyword for use as a method name. My fear is that it
> does not.
>
> This could definitely cramp our style, to put it mildly. Anyone know any
> more about this issue?
>
> Thanks,
> Noah Green
